ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I thought the course was paced well, required an appropriate amount of out-of-class time, lectures, and focus on the Electricity Strategy Game.I thought the course could use a little more explanation about the electricity strategy game before beginning the game, especially some more guidance or instruction on how to build a marginal cost model before splitting into groups and devising strategies for bidding on generation portfolios. I come from a power development background and have a pretty good handle on how elctricity markets work, but wanted to learn a bit more about the economics behind developing bidding strategies. Maybe one more class or two more class sessions could be devoted to this so that all the groups are on the same playing field? I ended up not contributing much to this early, but particularly critical, part of the course. I'm sure that disappointed my teammates, though I made up for it in later rounds of the game b/c they didn't have much of a background in carbon regulations or policy development.
The energy market simulation was a great way to reinforce the course material and theory. It was also a lot of fun to get to work with non-FES students on something other than a paper.
There were aspects of the game that could have been better organized by the TA.

The Energy Strategy Game was very well designed AND integrated into the course! I would have liked to spend more time with the readings to get a full sense of energy markets, in depth. I recommend this course be allowed to spread into a full semester. It would have been helpful to spend time looking at historical data of NG, oil, coal markets and understand the drivers of their fluctuations and who the market movers are.
The ESG and the readings.
The practical experience we got through the electricity strategy game. it gave a first hand experience to help us understand how electricity companies think.
Simulation and Professor's willingness to answer student questions in detail
The Energy Strategy Game. Worked on a strong team of students and learned a lot from my SOM colleagues.
Class time was well spent covering mix of theoretical, current papers, and electricity strategy game. Professor was very approachable and coordinated class discussion well.
The professor,the TA, the electricity strategy game, classmates, readings, I loved it all

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: see answer in Question 11.
Pace at the beginning was too fast for some. Several were scared away by the portfolio bidding process.
everything was great.
Getting more out of the readings and going into energy markets in more depth.
Nothing

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were available when needed.
Very fast turn around usually.
Both parties responded to e-mails within 24 hours. Very accessible.
The TA was available to answer questions I had about excel. Helped me a lot with my work in the class and other questions.
Very eager to answer questions and respond to emails.
Superior, Simon was amazing

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It provides an important perspective into electricity markets, though is a little less comprehensive than I might have expected for overall renewable markets. Still, it is such a broad topic and there's only so much to cover in a few weeks, so I understand the crunch
It definitely gave me a better understanding of how electricity markets work and the difficulties of integrating renewables into the grid.
This course provides some key background on electricity and fossil fuel markets. This is vital to my program which is on energy economics and environmental policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Come from an energy background and want to keep refining my knowledge on the subject(s).
I wanted an introduction to energy markets.
Interest in energy and markets

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, aside from the shortcomings noted in Question 11.
Yes.
Yes, and more.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Disadvantages: my economic background is minimial and my groupmates had a lot of econ experience. They practically built the portfolio bidding model and left me in the dust.Advantages: I contributed more in later rounds.It struck the balance that was intended, though I felt sort of lost and technically disadvantaged at first.

It was hard to coordinate group strategy when the turnover of electricity strategy game was several times a week. But it integrated different perspectives into the strategy (since everyone had different backgrounds)

I think I was clear about the advantages above. The disadvantage was in the initial meetings people with less economic backgrounds were not able to contribute as much (and some left the class) because they simply had not had enough time with the material to be able to help.

The Energy Strategy Game. It was a great exercise and helped me to gain a firm grasp of energy markets. Probably one of the most useful classes I've taken at Yale. I was also able to apply a lot of what I learned in Environmental Economics in this course.
Learned from each other!

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Hit the ground running! most of the critical work for the ESG takes place early and your team needs to be on the same page.
Readings before class helped immensely, especially in the earlier lectures.
The readings are fascinating. Take advantage of the opportunity to work with a diverse group of students.
Do the reading, know how to model in Excel
